reviewText:
Woodcutter Simulator 2013's environment is very pastoral and eerily serene. Set in a presumably German valley, the player can hear a constant and unyielding cacophony of chirping of birds in the distance.

With regard to the presentation of violence against trees, you're limited to accepting a contract with specifically designated markers. In order to fulfill this, the player walks towards the tree, checks the radar on the bottom right, and begins to rip into that deciduous flesh. Upon felling the great beasts with the chainsaw you'll hear their moaning creaks and be treated to a third person perspective of the tree collapsing.

Unfortunately the engine does not model physics too well and you're not free to hack away at trees. The act of cutting down a tree is simply a matter of pressing a button and watching an animation. So with all of this in mind I'd say that only simulation devotees and people like myself who enjoy investigating the curios of Steam should pick up this title.

reviewText:
I launched this game with some hope. That hope started to die away as I heard the hideous title music, steriotypical of most simulators. I pushed it aside, and continued to browse the menu. I was vaguely impressed by the animation from the main menu to the options menu, and was impressed further still with the video settings. The audios settings were detailed enough, however the controller settings didn't exist. The only options were to invery the 'y' axis and change sensitivity, nothing to do with the actual assignments. So I clicked 'New game'. It gave me the option to do a tutorial or start. So I clicked tutorial, only to descover to tutorial to be a low quality video lacking any form of audio. So, I weeped inside as I saw the last flicker of hope die away, but still I continued and started the game.

The game loaded quickly, for me to be stood with a chainsaw, and no form of instructions on how to move or do anything. So, I used my instints and placed my fingers on WASD. Surely enough, I moved as normal. However, when it came to looking around, moving the mouse only moved an on-screen cursor, not changing the direction I was looking at all. Again, I used my instincts and held the right mouse button and moved the mouse again, this time the camera moved. I cried some more as I moved about, being forced to strain my finger by having to hold right click for the whole period of play, similar to 'Roblox'. The difference with 'Roblox', however, is that 'Roblox' has some redeeming features. 'Woodcutter Simulator 2013' however, does not. I then attempted to acheive something in the game. I pressed space, expecting to jump, as the game told me I was in the wrong position to use the machine. I so assumed jumping didn't exist. It may still do, but the game seems to lack a control guide of any description, so I can never know. There was a gloing booklet on the UI, and I clicked it. It brought up a quest to chop 4 trees down in the New Forest and an option to accept, decline, or cancel. I clicked accept and a 1 1/2 hour timer came up with 0/4 trees chopped down. I looked at the godawful minimap in the top left and assumed the large tree was my destination. Sure enough, when I got there there was a glowing arrow above it. On my way, I discoved something the game DOESN'T lack in; Invisible walls. I spent a long time trying to find my way around them, like some sort of sick, twisted maze. I wandered around, hoping to find some option to cut a tree down, and none appeared. Some trees had yellow bands on them, and so I walked up to one of them. A radar with a dot on appeared in the bottom right, and I used common sense to figure that the tree was the dot. I got the dot in the centre of the radar, and pressed space. I then started to cut the tree down. About 40 SECONDS later, the tree finally toppled. It's leaves then popped off, throwing the tree into a wild spasm. I was then released from the cutscene, only to find the tree had not registered as one of the 4 I had to chop down. About 20 seconds later, it registered, and I moved onto the other 3. I finished this, only to find yet another quest to chop down 3 more trees a 5 minute walk away. That's 5 minutes PLUS finding your way around invisible walls. I still feel like I have acheived precisely nothing after 2 quests and a whole lot of finger strain.

Overall, this game is utter ♥♥♥♥♥. An ocean with the depth of a tide pool. Drowning in mediocrity.
2/10 for you number-hunting ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Do not recommend.

reviewText:
Oh what a gift this was! This was my first Simulator game, and my oh my what a terrible experience it was.

This game is riddled with bugs, which makes me question whether it even went through any quality control what so ever. The first bug I experienced was a lack of control of where the hell my guy was moving, at first I thought my 360 controller fell off my tower again and the analogue stick was wedged forward, but sadly it was not the case. Other bugs which players may encounter are:
- Loading a save game and falling through the world.
- Just falling through the world in general randomly.
- Trees falling through the world after being cut down.
- Trees falling on vehicles and knocking them over.
- Sprinting into a vehicle can launch the player into the sky (Actually the best part of the game when I got it to work).
- Driving through trees!
- Random invisible walls when trying to skip across the terrain when the objective is just behind the hill you're trying to get over.
- Trees not falling over after cutting them, which means you need to shunt it with a vehicle for it to fall. Otherwise you can't cut down another tree...
- Random game crashes
Other than the horde of bugs, sorry I mean features, which this game has to offer it lacks a tutorial which informs you how you actually play this game e.g. how and what trees you are allowed to cut down. This was not so obvious at first, this teaches me for not playing the 2012 version eh? Anyway, there are video 'tutorials', but the videos are just soundless with text displayed at the bottom giving you of very little detail, maybe the developers couldn't record them selves talking without laughing hysterically at what they've thrown together. These videos also don't play some times, I had to restart the game a couple of times in order to to watch all of the videos.

The map is fairly big and you have no vehicle to help get you around any quicker. But you know, having vehicles in this game is rather pointless because all you need to do is sprint and move diagonally in order to launch yourself across the map to get to where ever you wanted to go. You don't even need to change 'location' to cut the trees you need, you can stay in the same area for a couple of missions until all the cut-able trees are gone, then you sadly have to move once again across the map to cut that last tree you need to earn that sweet sweet 3,000 something. I have no idea what the currency is in this game, perhaps you're paid in wood for the wood you've just wooded (Sounded a lot better in my head).

I could go on and on about the many delights which this game has to offer, but I will say this...It is a terrible game with no clear goal to start with or to continue with. There is no real involvement in cutting the trees, you just need to position yourself and hit the 'GO' button. This game is not worth the full price, nor is it worth half price. At best this game is a gag game to give your friend on his birthday, or a game to gift some one just to show them how much you loathe them.

Can't wait for Woodcutter Simulator 2014.

* Slow frame rate on integrated graphics cards. Although my Intel HD 4000 card is quite adequate to play Portal and Demolition simulator at full resolution. For Woodcutter you need a high end card.
